On Thu, 2003-04-10 at 10:55, Scott Palmer wrote: I just thought I would
point out that (at least according to some) 
there is no such thing as a 'static inner class'.  An 'inner' class 
MUST be bound to an instance of the outer class, and thus can't be 
static.  What you are talking about here I think is referred to as a 
'nested' class.  Which is declared exactly like you would expect a 
'static inner class' to be declared if that's what it was called:-).  I 
remember hearing the term 'top level nested class'  I think it was in 
an article on jRoundup.com.


I don't agree.  For one reason, the type-safe-enum pattern is still a
viable pattern.  I often use StICs to represent these.  I know that it
isn't necessary, but it helps a great deal in packaging my classes
according to intent of use.

Also, in my tests I will often times create a mock object as a StIC that
is either the only implementation of an interface/abstract class in the
testing world, or is just a very specific implementation of it.

I will post examples if anyone is interested.

=jason
